Dynamic Privacy Allocation for Locally Differentially Private
Federated Learning with Composite Objectives

Abstract

This paper proposes a locally differentially private federated learning algorithm for strongly convex but possibly nonsmooth problems that protects the gradients of each worker against an honest but curious server. The proposed algorithm adds artificial noise to the shared information to ensure privacy and dynamically allocates the time-varying noise variance to minimize an upper bound of the optimization error subject to a predefined privacy budget constraint. This allows for an arbitrarily large but finite number of iterations to achieve both privacy protection and utility up to a neighborhood of the optimal solution, removing the need for tuning the number of iterations. Numerical results show the superiority of the proposed algorithm over state-of-the-art methods.

Index Terms—  Federated Learning, Local Differential Privacy, Dynamic Allocation

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) [1] is a popular distributed machine learning framework where a set of workers collaborate on model training through a server without sharing their local data. Not only does this enable efficient parallel computations, but it also provides privacy advantages compared to centralized machine learning methods. Unfortunately, even though the data is not directly shared, FL can still result in privacy leakage [2]. This is because the information communicated between the workers and the server, such as local gradients or models, is derived from the raw data. As the number of iterations increases, the accumulated shared information during the training process may pose a privacy risk [2].

One way to approach privacy protection is through the lens of cryptography. However, in many FL scenarios, these techniques suffer from high communication and computation costs [3]. Currently, Differential Privacy (DP) [4, 5] has been more successful in FL, since it is easy to implement, has a good privacy protection effect, and allows to rigorously quantify the strength of the privacy protection [5]. The design of DP algorithms in federated learning depends on the attack scenario and can be roughly divided into global DP and local DP (LDP) [6, 7]. Global DP resists passive attackers from outside the system and typically relies on the server to add noise to the aggregated information while the workers upload their true models or gradients, assuming that the upload communication channel is secure and the server is trustworthy [6]. In contrast, LDP protects sensitive information against an honest but curious server during the training process and does not rely on secure uploading channels [7]. Instead, each worker adds noise to its local sensitive information before sending it to the server. The challenge of LDP is that it may require more noise to be added, which can lead to a serious deterioration of the utility (e.g. the expected value of the total loss function). A number of studies have been dedicated to proposing algorithms with better privacy-utility trade-off [8, 9]. One example of such a technique is the recently proposed DP-SCAFFOLD [8], which combines LDP with SCAFFOLD [10]. It analyzes the trade-off between privacy and utility and demonstrates the superior performance of DP-SCAFFOLD compared to DP-FedAvg [11], especially for heterogeneous data. The work in [9] proposes ISRL-DP to solve problems with convex constraints. However, all the works mentioned above face the issue that the optimization error bound is sensitive to the total number of iterations when the privacy budget is finite. Therefore, the total number of iterations becomes a hyperparameter, which needs to be chosen carefully to minimize the optimization error. Either too few or too many iterations reduce the utility, which brings difficulties to the practical use of the algorithm.

Contribution. We propose an LDP FL algorithm for strongly convex but possibly nonsmooth problems that protects worker gradients from an honest but curious server. Our algorithm adds artificial noise to shared information for privacy protection. A dynamic allocation of the noise variance minimizes the optimization error under a predefined privacy budget constraint. As a result, the optimization error caused by the privacy-protecting noise is independent of the total number of iterations, allowing us to execute an arbitrarily large but finite number of iterations for privacy and utility without worrying that a too large number of iterations will cause the optimization error to diverge. Our numerical results show a distinct superiority of the proposed algorithm over state-of-the-art methods. Table 1 summarizes the comparison with the state-of-the-art methods.

2 Problem Formulation and LDP

In this section, we introduce the problem formulation for FL and review some preliminaries on LDP.

2.1 Problem Formulation

In our FL scenario, a server coordinates n𝑛n workers to collaboratively train a joint model with d𝑑d parameters. Each worker, denoted by i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], possesses a private data set 𝒟i=⋃l=1m𝒟i​lsubscript𝒟𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑚subscript𝒟𝑖𝑙\mathcal{D}_{i}=\bigcup_{l=1}^{m}\mathcal{D}_{il} comprising the m𝑚m data points 𝒟i​1,…,𝒟i​msubscript𝒟𝑖1…subscript𝒟𝑖𝑚\mathcal{D}_{i1},\dots,\mathcal{D}_{im}. We support heterogeneous data and do not require that the data sets 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} are similar. Our goal is to solve composite problems on the form

minimizex∈ℝd1n​∑i=1nfi​(x)+g​(x),fi​(x)=1m​∑l=1mfi​l​(x).subscriptminimize𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥𝑔𝑥subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑚subscript𝑓𝑖𝑙𝑥\displaystyle\operatorname*{minimize}_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}~{}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x)+g(x),~{}f_{i}(x)=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{l=1}^{m}f_{il}(x). (1)

In this context, fi​l​(x)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑙𝑥f_{il}(x) represents the sample loss associated with data point 𝒟i​lsubscript𝒟𝑖𝑙\mathcal{D}_{il}, while the loss function fi​(x)subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥f_{i}(x) measures the dissimilarity between the model’s predictions using parameter x𝑥x and the actual labels in the data set 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. Additionally, g𝑔g serves as a regularizer that promotes desired properties of the solution, such as sparsity. To address (1) in the FL setting, we introduce a local copy xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} of the decision vector x𝑥x for each worker i𝑖i and reformulate the problem as

Throughout the paper, we make the following assumptions on f𝑓f and g𝑔g.

Assumption 2.1

The loss function f:ℝn​d↦ℝ:𝑓maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑛𝑑ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{nd}\mapsto\mathbb{R} is both μfsubscript𝜇𝑓\mu_{f}-strongly convex and Lfsubscript𝐿𝑓L_{f}-smooth, i.e. for any 𝐱,𝐲∈ℝn​d𝐱𝐲superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{nd},

f​(𝐲)≥f​(𝐱)+∇f​(𝐱)T​(𝐲−𝐱)+μf2​‖𝐲−𝐱‖2,𝑓𝐲𝑓𝐱∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑇𝐲𝐱subscript𝜇𝑓2superscriptnorm𝐲𝐱2f(\mathbf{y})\geq f(\mathbf{x})+\nabla f(\mathbf{x})^{T}(\mathbf{y}-\mathbf{x})+\frac{\mu_{f}}{2}\|\mathbf{y}-\mathbf{x}\|^{2},

where μf>0subscript𝜇𝑓0\mu_{f}>0 and Lf>0subscript𝐿𝑓0L_{f}>0 denote the strong convexity constant and smoothness constant, respectively. Additionally, we assume that g:ℝd↦ℝ:𝑔maps-tosuperscriptℝ𝑑ℝg:\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R} is a closed and proper convex function, which may not necessarily be smooth.

2.2 Local Differential Privacy

We consider a threat model in which an honest-but-curious server has access to all the messages shared by the workers during the training process, as studied in [8]. We aim to protect each gradient ∇fi​l∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑙\nabla f_{il} for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] and l∈[m]𝑙delimited-[]𝑚l\in[m]. Thus, we say that ∇fi∇subscript𝑓𝑖\nabla f_{i} and ∇fi′∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′\nabla f_{i}^{\prime} is a pair of adjacent inputs of worker i𝑖i if only a single gradient (e.g. l~~𝑙\tilde{l}-th) is different, i.e., ∇fi​l~≠∇fi​l~′∇subscript𝑓𝑖~𝑙∇subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖~𝑙\nabla f_{i\tilde{l}}\neq\nabla f^{\prime}_{i\tilde{l}} while ∇fi​l=∇fi​l′∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑙∇subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖𝑙\nabla f_{il}=\nabla f^{\prime}_{il} for any l≠l~𝑙~𝑙l\neq\tilde{l}. With this definition of adjacent inputs, we give the following definition of LDP.

Definition 2.2 ((ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP)

For any adjacent inputs ∇fi∇subscript𝑓𝑖\nabla f_{i} and ∇fi′∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′\nabla f_{i}^{\prime} of worker i𝑖i, a randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP if for every O⊂Range​(𝒜)𝑂Range𝒜O\subset\text{Range}(\mathcal{A}) where Range​(𝒜)Range𝒜\text{Range}(\mathcal{A}) is the output space of 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}, we have

Pr⁡[𝒜​(∇fi)∈O]≤eϵ​Pr⁡[𝒜​(∇fi′)∈O]+δ.Pr𝒜∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑂superscript𝑒italic-ϵPr𝒜∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′𝑂𝛿{\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(\nabla f_{i})\in O]}\leq e^{\epsilon}{\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{A}(\nabla f_{i}^{\prime})\in O]}+\delta. (4)

When ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon and δ𝛿\delta are sufficiently small, the outputs generated by any pair of adjacent inputs ∇fi∇subscript𝑓𝑖\nabla f_{i} and ∇fi′∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′\nabla f_{i}^{\prime} are almost identical, which makes it difficult for attackers to distinguish between them. One prototypical method for achieving (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP is the Gaussian Mechanism, which adds Gaussian noise 𝒩​(0,ξ2​Id)𝒩0superscript𝜉2subscript𝐼𝑑\mathcal{N}(0,\xi^{2}I_{d}) to a real-valued query function 𝒬:∇fi↦ℝd:𝒬maps-to∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{Q}:\nabla f_{i}\mapsto\mathbb{R}^{d} to perturb the true answer. The variance of the noise that one needs to add depends on the sensitivity of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} [4].

Definition 2.3 (Sensitivity)

For any adjacent inputs ∇fi∇subscript𝑓𝑖\nabla f_{i} and ∇fi′∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′\nabla f_{i}^{\prime}, the sensitivity of a query function 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is defined as Δ𝒬=max∇fi,∇fi′⁡‖𝒬​(∇fi)−𝒬​(∇fi′)‖.subscriptΔ𝒬subscript∇subscript𝑓𝑖∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′norm𝒬∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒬∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′\Delta_{\mathcal{Q}}=\max_{\nabla f_{i},\nabla f_{i}^{\prime}}\|\mathcal{Q}(\nabla f_{i})-\mathcal{Q}(\nabla f_{i}^{\prime})\|.

To ensure a desired level of privacy, a higher variance is needed when the sensitivity Δ𝒬subscriptΔ𝒬\Delta_{\mathcal{Q}} is higher [4]. Applying a differentially private mechanism repeatedly increases the privacy loss. We use zero-concentrated differential privacy (ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP [12]) as an analytical tool to track the privacy loss of our algorithm across iterations. The ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP captures the privacy properties of repeated Gaussian mechanisms better than analyzing each iteration separately via (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP [12]. The total ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP bound can then be converted back to (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP.

3 Algorithm Development

Next, we introduce our LDP FL algorithm for solving (1) with a predefined privacy budget. The algorithm relies on the following primal-dual formulation of (3)

minimize𝐱∈ℝn​dmaximize𝐲∈ℝn​d⁡f​(𝐱)+g​(𝐱)+⟨𝐲,𝐋𝐱⟩,subscriptminimize𝐱superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑subscriptmaximize𝐲superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑𝑓𝐱𝑔𝐱𝐲𝐋𝐱\operatorname*{minimize}_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{nd}}\;\operatorname*{maximize}_{\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{nd}}~{}f(\mathbf{x})+g(\mathbf{x})+\langle\mathbf{y},\mathbf{L}\mathbf{x}\rangle, (5)

where 𝐲∈ℝn​d𝐲superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{nd} is the dual variable of the equality constraint in (3). To solve (5), we adopt an approach that alternates between computing an approximate primal solution for a fixed dual variable and performing a (sub)gradient ascent step in the dual variable for a fixed primal variable [13, 14]. In addition, we use the Gaussian mechanism to protect gradients. In principle, we would like to run the iterations

(6)

where ∇f​(𝐱t)=[1n​∇f1​(x1t);…;1n​∇fn​(xnt)]∈ℝn​d∇𝑓superscript𝐱𝑡1𝑛∇subscript𝑓1superscriptsubscript𝑥1𝑡…1𝑛∇subscript𝑓𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑡superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{t})=[\frac{1}{n}\nabla f_{1}(x_{1}^{t});\ldots;\frac{1}{n}\nabla f_{n}(x_{n}^{t})]\in\mathbb{R}^{nd}, 𝜻t=[ζ1t;…;ζnt]∈ℝn​dsuperscript𝜻𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜁1𝑡…superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑛𝑡superscriptℝ𝑛𝑑\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{t}=[\zeta_{1}^{t};\ldots;\zeta_{n}^{t}]\in\mathbb{R}^{nd}, and ζit∼𝒩​(0,ξt2​Id)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑡𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2subscript𝐼𝑑\zeta_{i}^{t}\sim\mathcal{N}\left(0,\xi_{t}^{2}I_{d}\right) for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]. To ensure LDP, we would therefore need to also protect the dual variables 𝐲tsuperscript𝐲𝑡\mathbf{y}^{t} when they are communicated to the server to evaluate 𝐋𝐲tsuperscript𝐋𝐲𝑡\mathbf{L}\mathbf{y}^{t}. However, since 𝐋2=𝐋superscript𝐋2𝐋\mathbf{L}^{2}=\mathbf{L}, we can introduce 𝚲t=𝐋𝐲tsuperscript𝚲𝑡superscript𝐋𝐲𝑡\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{t}=\mathbf{L}\mathbf{y}^{t} with 𝚲1=0n​dsuperscript𝚲1subscript0𝑛𝑑\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{1}=0_{nd} and re-write the iterations (6) as

{𝐱~t+1=𝐱t−γ​(∇f​(𝐱t)+𝜻t+𝚲t),𝚲t+1=𝚲t+𝐋​𝐱~t+1,𝐳t+1=(𝐈−γ​𝐋)​𝐱~t+1,𝐱t+1=proxγn​g​(𝐳t+1).\left\{\begin{aligned} \widetilde{\mathbf{x}}^{t+1}&=\mathbf{x}^{t}-\gamma\left(\nabla f(\mathbf{x}^{t})+{\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{t}}+\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{t}\right),\\ \boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{t+1}&=\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{t}+\mathbf{L}\widetilde{\mathbf{x}}^{t+1},\\ \mathbf{z}^{t+1}&=\left(\mathbf{I}-\gamma\mathbf{L}\right)\widetilde{\mathbf{x}}^{t+1},\\ \mathbf{x}^{t+1}&=\mathrm{prox}_{\frac{\gamma}{n}g}(\mathbf{z}^{t+1}).\end{aligned}\right. (7)

Unlike (6), the updates in (7) only require the communication of the obfuscated local models 𝐱~t+1superscript~𝐱𝑡1\widetilde{\mathbf{x}}^{t+1} to update 𝚲t+1superscript𝚲𝑡1\boldsymbol{\Lambda}^{t+1} and 𝐳t+1superscript𝐳𝑡1\mathbf{z}^{t+1}. The implementation of (7) is given in Algorithm 1.

4 Analysis

In this section, we first perform separate analyses of the privacy and utility of the proposed algorithm. Then, we perform a joint privacy-utility analysis under a dynamic allocation of the variance of the injected noise and give the resulting convergence rate. All proofs can be found in Appendix A.

4.1 Separate Analysis of Privacy and Utility

We make the following assumption on the injected noise.

Assumption 4.1

At any time step t𝑡t and for every worker i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], the injected noise variables ζitsuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑡\zeta_{i}^{t} are independent and follow a Gaussian distribution with mean 0 and variance ξt2​Idsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2subscript𝐼𝑑\xi_{t}^{2}I_{d}.

To ensure bounded sensitivity, we need ∇fi​(xit)∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡\nabla f_{i}(x_{i}^{t}) to be bounded for all i𝑖i and t𝑡t. The convexity of fisubscript𝑓𝑖f_{i} simplifies this requirement to the boundedness of xitsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{t} [15, Prop. B.24]. To achieve this, we make specific assumptions on the regularizer g𝑔g.

Assumption 4.2

The proximal operator of the regularizer, proxg​(z)=arg⁡minx∈ℝd⁡g​(x)+12​‖z−x‖2subscriptprox𝑔𝑧subscript𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑𝑔𝑥12superscriptnorm𝑧𝑥2\mathrm{prox}_{g}(z)=\arg\min_{x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}g(x)+\tfrac{1}{2}\|z-x\|^{2}, is both easy to compute and bounded.

We present two examples of g𝑔g that satisfy Assumption 4.2:

(1) The indicator function of a convex and compact set which is easy to project onto. When g𝑔g is the indicator function of a convex set, the proximal operator reduces to the projection operator, which is bounded if the underlying set is.

(2) The weighted ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm over a box [16, Example 6.23])

g​(z)={∑j=1dωj​|zj|,−α​1d≤z≤α​1d,∞, else, 𝑔𝑧casessuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝜔𝑗subscript𝑧𝑗𝛼subscript1𝑑𝑧𝛼subscript1𝑑 else, g(z)=\begin{cases}\sum_{j=1}^{d}\omega_{j}\left|z_{j}\right|,&-{\alpha}1_{d}\leq z\leq{\alpha}1_{d},\\ \infty,&\text{ else, }\end{cases}

where ωj>0subscript𝜔𝑗0\omega_{j}>0, α>0𝛼0\alpha>0, and zj∈ℝsubscript𝑧𝑗ℝz_{j}\in\mathbb{R} is the j𝑗j-th entry of z𝑧z. We can express g​(z)𝑔𝑧g(z) as g​(z)=∑j=1dgj​(zj)𝑔𝑧superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑑subscript𝑔𝑗subscript𝑧𝑗g(z)=\sum_{j=1}^{d}g_{j}(z_{j}), where gj​(zj)=ωj​|zj|subscript𝑔𝑗subscript𝑧𝑗subscript𝜔𝑗subscript𝑧𝑗g_{j}(z_{j})=\omega_{j}|z_{j}| if −α≤zj≤α,𝛼subscript𝑧𝑗𝛼-\alpha\leq z_{j}\leq\alpha, and gj​(zj)=∞subscript𝑔𝑗subscript𝑧𝑗g_{j}(z_{j})=\infty otherwise. The j𝑗j-th entry of proxg​(z)subscriptprox𝑔𝑧\mathrm{prox}_{g}(z), defined by [proxg​(z)]jsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptprox𝑔𝑧𝑗[\mathrm{prox}_{g}(z)]_{j}, is given by

With Assumption 4.2, we know that there exists a constant 0<B<∞0𝐵0<B<\infty so that, for all possible sequences {𝐱t}tsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑡𝑡\{\mathbf{x}^{t}\}_{t} generated by Algorithm 1,

‖∇fi​l​(xit)‖≤B​ for all ​i,t​ and ​l.norm∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝐵 for all 𝑖𝑡 and 𝑙\|\nabla f_{il}(x_{i}^{t})\|\leq B~{}\mbox{ for all }i,t\mbox{ and }l. (8)

Since we aim to ensure that the messages {x~it}tsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑡\{\widetilde{x}_{i}^{t}\}_{t} preserve (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP for each gradient ∇fi∇subscript𝑓𝑖\nabla f_{i}, we establish the following lemma to bound the total privacy loss.

Lemma 4.3

Let Assumptions 4.1 and 4.2 be satisfied. Then, for each worker i𝑖i, the message sequence {x~it}tsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑡\{\widetilde{x}_{i}^{t}\}_{t} generated by Algorithm 1 is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, with ϵ=ρtgt+2​ρtgt​ln⁡(1/δ),italic-ϵsubscript𝜌tgt2subscript𝜌tgt1𝛿\epsilon=\rho_{\rm tgt}+2\sqrt{\rho_{\rm tgt}\ln({1}/{\delta})}, where ρtgt=∑t=1T2​B2/(n2​m2​ξt2)subscript𝜌tgtsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇2superscript𝐵2superscript𝑛2superscript𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2\rho_{\rm tgt}=\sum_{t=1}^{T}2B^{2}/(n^{2}m^{2}\xi_{t}^{2}).

Although we state this guarantee for the messages {x~it}tsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑡\{\widetilde{x}_{i}^{t}\}_{t}, it also holds for the iterates {xit}tsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑡\{x_{i}^{t}\}_{t} because xitsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡x_{i}^{t} is a data-independent post-processing of x~itsuperscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑡\widetilde{x}_{i}^{t} [5]. As shown in Lemma 4.3, the larger the variance ξt2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2\xi_{t}^{2}, the stronger the privacy protection. Further, we have the freedom to allocate the variances ξt2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2\xi_{t}^{2} over time to guarantee that ρtgtsubscript𝜌tgt\rho_{\rm tgt}, and hence the total privacy loss ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, is no more than a given privacy budget.

Next, we focus on the utility. To handle the randomness caused by ζitsuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖𝑡\zeta_{i}^{t} for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], we let ℱtsuperscriptℱ𝑡\mathcal{F}^{t} be the event generated by ⋃i∈[n]t~∈[t−1]ζit~superscriptsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛~𝑡delimited-[]𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑖~𝑡\bigcup_{i\in[n]}^{\tilde{t}\in[t-1]}\zeta_{i}^{\tilde{t}}. Let (𝐱⋆,𝐲⋆)superscript𝐱⋆superscript𝐲⋆(\mathbf{x}^{\star},\mathbf{y}^{\star}) be a pair of primal-dual optimal solutions to the constrained problem (3). We define the Lyapunov function Φt=‖𝐱t−𝐱⋆‖2+γ​‖𝐲t−𝐲⋆‖2superscriptΦ𝑡superscriptnormsuperscript𝐱𝑡superscript𝐱⋆2𝛾superscriptnormsuperscript𝐲𝑡superscript𝐲⋆2\Phi^{t}=\left\|\mathbf{x}^{t}-\mathbf{x}^{\star}\right\|^{2}+{\gamma}\left\|\mathbf{y}^{t}-\mathbf{y}^{\star}\right\|^{2} and derive the following recursion.

Under Assumptions 2.1 and 4.1, for Algorithm 1, if γ≤min⁡{1/4,1/Lf},𝛾141subscript𝐿𝑓\gamma\leq\min\left\{{1}/{4},{1}/{L_{f}}\right\}, then the sequence {Φt}tsubscriptsuperscriptΦ𝑡𝑡\{\Phi^{t}\}_{t} satisfies

𝔼​[Φt+1]≤(1−γ​min⁡{μf,1})​𝔼​[Φt]+52​n​d​γ2​ξt2.𝔼delimited-[]superscriptΦ𝑡11𝛾subscript𝜇𝑓1𝔼delimited-[]superscriptΦ𝑡52𝑛𝑑superscript𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\Phi^{t+1}\right]\leq\left(1-\gamma\min\left\{{\mu_{f}},1\right\}\right)\mathbb{E}\left[\Phi^{t}\right]+\tfrac{5}{2}{nd\gamma^{2}}\xi_{t}^{2}. (9)

Lemma 4.4 demonstrates that 𝔼​[Φt+1]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptΦ𝑡1\mathbb{E}\left[\Phi^{t+1}\right] decreases by a factor (1−γ​min⁡{μf,1})1𝛾subscript𝜇𝑓1\left(1-\gamma\min\left\{{\mu_{f}},1\right\}\right) but is also inflated by an additive term 52​n​d​γ2​ξt252𝑛𝑑superscript𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2\tfrac{5}{2}{nd\gamma^{2}}\xi_{t}^{2} caused by the privacy noise. By Lemma 4.3, if we use a static variance, i.e., let ξt2=2​B2​T/(ρtgt​n2​m2),∀t∈[T]formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡22superscript𝐵2𝑇subscript𝜌tgtsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝑚2for-all𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\xi_{t}^{2}=2B^{2}T/(\rho_{\rm tgt}n^{2}m^{2}),~{}\forall t\in[T], to meet the target value of ρtgtsubscript𝜌tgt\rho_{\rm tgt} over the T𝑇T iterations, the error term in the optimization error bound caused by privacy-protecting noise will diverge as T𝑇T grows large, as shown in [8, 9]. However, by telescoping (9), we observe that noise added earlier has a smaller effect on the total error at iteration T𝑇T. This observation inspires us to allocate larger variances at earlier stages. We develop the precise mechanism for variance selection next.

4.2 Privacy-Utility Analysis with Dynamic Allocation

Lemma 4.3 characterizes the amount of variance required to ensure (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP, while Lemma 4.4 quantifies the impact of the noise variance on the utility. Next, we conduct a joint analysis of the privacy and the utility under a dynamic allocation of the time-varying variances.

Theorem 4.5

Let Assumptions 2.1, 4.1, and 4.2 be satisfied. Then, for an arbitrarily large but finite T𝑇T and given privacy parameters ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 and δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), if

γ≤min⁡{1/4,1/Lf}𝛾141subscript𝐿𝑓\gamma\leq\min\left\{{1}/{4},{1}/{L_{f}}\right\} (10)

and the noise variances are allocated as

ξt2=π/qt,∀t∈[T],formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2𝜋subscript𝑞𝑡for-all𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\xi_{t}^{2}=\sqrt{{\pi}/{q_{t}}},\quad\forall t\in[T], (11)

where qt=(1−γ​min⁡{μf,1})T−tsubscript𝑞𝑡superscript1𝛾subscript𝜇𝑓1𝑇𝑡q_{t}=(1-\gamma\min\{\mu_{f},1\})^{T-t} and π=𝜋absent\sqrt{\pi}= 2​B2​∑t=1Tqt2superscript𝐵2superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑞𝑡2B^{2}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sqrt{q_{t}} (ρtgt​n2​m2)−1superscriptsubscript𝜌tgtsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝑚21(\rho_{\rm tgt}n^{2}m^{2})^{-1}, then the utility of Algorithm 1 satisfies

+20​B2​d(ϵ+ln⁡1δ−ln⁡1δ)2​n​m2​min⁡{μf2,1}20superscript𝐵2𝑑superscriptitalic-ϵ1𝛿1𝛿2𝑛superscript𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑓21\displaystyle+\tfrac{20B^{2}d}{\left(\sqrt{\epsilon+\ln\tfrac{1}{\delta}}-\sqrt{\ln\tfrac{1}{\delta}}\right)^{2}nm^{2}\min\left\{\mu_{f}^{2},1\right\}}

and, for each worker i𝑖i, the message sequence {x~it}tsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript~𝑥𝑖𝑡𝑡\{\widetilde{x}_{i}^{t}\}_{t} satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP with

ϵ=ρtgt+2​ρtgt​ln⁡(1/δ).italic-ϵsubscript𝜌tgt2subscript𝜌tgt1𝛿\epsilon=\rho_{\rm tgt}+2\sqrt{\rho_{\rm tgt}\ln({1}/{\delta})}. (13)

With Theorem 4.5, given an LDP privacy budget (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta), we first choose ρtgtsubscript𝜌tgt\rho_{\rm tgt} such that (13) is satisfied. We then set γ𝛾\gamma according to (10), and finally allocate the variances ξt2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡2\xi_{t}^{2} using (11). With these choices, for any arbitrarily large but finite T𝑇T, the sequence {𝐱t}tsubscriptsuperscript𝐱𝑡𝑡\{\mathbf{x}^{t}\}_{t} generated by Algorithm 1 converges in expectation to a neighborhood of the optimal solution of (3) that is of order 𝒪​(B2​d​ln⁡(1/δ)/(ϵ2​n​m2​min⁡{μf2,1}))𝒪superscript𝐵2𝑑1𝛿superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑛superscript𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑓21\mathcal{O}({B^{2}d\ln({1}/{\delta}})/(\epsilon^{2}nm^{2}\min\{{\mu_{f}^{2}},1\})), while also ensuring (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP. The dynamic allocation strategy used in the proposed algorithm employs a geometrically decreasing variance and allows to attain a stable performance also for large values of T𝑇T; cf. Section 5.1 below.

5 Numerical Experiments

We compare Algorithm 1 with three state-of-the-art algorithms: DP-FedAvg [8], DP-SCAFFOLD [8], and ISRL-DP[9], which are all designed to resist an honest-but-curious server with a good privacy-utility trade-off but cannot handle nonsmooth terms such as g𝑔g in (1). Therefore, we conduct two sets of experiments. In the first set, we compare our algorithm with DP-FedAvg, DP-SCAFFOLD, and ISRL-DP for smooth problems to demonstrate its superiority. In the second set of experiments, we run our algorithm on nonsmooth problems under different settings to verify our theoretical results. We use standard benchmarking data sets from the libsvm repository111https://www.csie.ntu.edu.tw/~cjlin/libsvmtools/datasets/, run each experiment 20 times and plot the average results with error bars that represent the standard variance of the 20 runs. The optimal solution x⋆superscript𝑥⋆x^{\star} of problem (1) is calculated in advance. For all algorithms, we set the same privacy budget, (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-LDP with ϵ=1italic-ϵ1\epsilon=1 and δ=10−4𝛿superscript104\delta=10^{-4}, and compare their optimality errors defined as

optimality:=1n​∑i=1n‖x¯t−xit‖2+‖x¯t−x⋆‖2‖x⋆‖2.assignoptimality1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛superscriptnormsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡2superscriptnormsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡superscript𝑥⋆2superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥⋆2\text{optimality}:={\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\|\bar{x}^{t}-x_{i}^{t}\|^{2}}+\frac{\|\bar{x}^{t}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}{\|x^{\star}\|^{2}}}.

This quantity is used to reflect both the consensus error and the optimization error of the average. For the compared methods, since each worker receives the global model x¯tsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡\bar{x}^{t} from the server, the optimality error becomes ‖x¯t−x⋆‖2/‖x⋆‖2superscriptnormsuperscript¯𝑥𝑡superscript𝑥⋆2superscriptnormsuperscript𝑥⋆2{\|\bar{x}^{t}-x^{\star}\|^{2}}/{\|x^{\star}\|^{2}}.

Additional experiments on nonconvex nonsmooth problems can be found in Appendix A.

5.1 Smooth Problem

We consider an ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-regularized logistic regression problem

minx∈ℝd​1n​∑i=1nfi​(x)+ϑ22​‖x‖2,𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑min1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥subscriptitalic-ϑ22superscriptnorm𝑥2\displaystyle\underset{{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}{\operatorname{min}}\;\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x)+\frac{\vartheta_{2}}{2}\|x\|^{2},\vspace{-2mm} (14)

where fi​(x)=1m​∑l=1mln⁡(1+exp⁡(−(𝐚i​lT​x)​bi​l))subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥1𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝐚𝑖𝑙𝑇𝑥subscript𝑏𝑖𝑙f_{i}(x)=\tfrac{1}{m}\sum_{l=1}^{m}\ln\left(1+\exp\left(-\left(\mathbf{a}_{il}^{T}{x}\right)b_{il}\right)\right) is the loss of x𝑥x on the data held by worker i𝑖i, ϑ2subscriptitalic-ϑ2\vartheta_{2} is a regularization parameter, and (𝐚i​l,bi​l)∈ℝd×{−1,+1}subscript𝐚𝑖𝑙subscript𝑏𝑖𝑙superscriptℝ𝑑11(\mathbf{a}_{il},b_{il})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\{-1,+1\} is the feature-label pair of the l𝑙l-th sample of worker i𝑖i. We use the ijcnn dataset and set n=20𝑛20n=20, m=100𝑚100m=100, and ϑ2=0.1subscriptitalic-ϑ20.1\vartheta_{2}=0.1. We use full gradients in the learning process for all algorithms. It is worth noting that subsampling amplification used in [8, 9] helps to counteract the increased sensitivity that comes with using mini-batch stochastic gradients but it does not improve the expected utility beyond the use of full gradients. We retain local updates for DP-FedAvg and DP-SCAFFOLD to reduce their communication costs. We set the privacy budget as (1,10−4)1superscript104(1,10^{-4})-LDP and tune the parameters for the best performances. We evaluate 8 different values of the total communication rounds T𝑇T, ranging from 1000 to 8000 with an interval of 1000. For each algorithm, we report the final optimization error after T𝑇T communication rounds.

Fig. 1 shows the optimality error for different numbers of total communication rounds T𝑇T for the considered methods. The state-of-the-art algorithms initially improve with more iterations, but then deteriorate if T𝑇T is chosen too large. In contrast, the optimization error of our algorithm decreases initially and stabilizes in a neighborhood of the optimum as T𝑇T increases, indicating that there is no need to tune T𝑇T. As observed from the figure, DP-FedAvg outperforms ISRL-DP (due to its use of local updates). DP-SCAFFOLD achieves better results than DP-FedAvg by correcting for client drift. Our proposed algorithm surpasses DP-SCAFFOLD, because of the dynamic allocation strategy that maintains a stable performance also for very large values of T𝑇T.

5.2 Nonsmooth Problem

In this set of experiments, we consider the nonsmooth logistic regression problem

minx∈ℝd​1n​∑i=1nfi​(x)+ϑ22​‖x‖2+g​(x),𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑min1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥subscriptitalic-ϑ22superscriptnorm𝑥2𝑔𝑥\displaystyle\underset{{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}{\operatorname{min}}\;\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x)+\frac{\vartheta_{2}}{2}\|{x}\|^{2}+g(x), (15)

where g​(x)𝑔𝑥g(x) is the weighted ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm over a box defined in Section 4 with ωj=0.01subscript𝜔𝑗0.01\omega_{j}=0.01 for all j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d] and α=10𝛼10\alpha=10. Compared to problem (14), we add a nonsmooth regularizer g𝑔g, while all the other settings are the same. We use a6a dataset and set n=20𝑛20n=20, m=561𝑚561m=561, and ϑ2=0.1subscriptitalic-ϑ20.1\vartheta_{2}=0.1.

The aim of these experiments is to verify that our algorithm can run for a large but finite T𝑇T while ensuring (1,10−4)1superscript104(1,10^{-4})-LDP also on nonsmooth problems. To do so, we set different values of T𝑇T ranging from 1000 to 5000, and show the evolution of the optimality error across communication rounds t=1,2,…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2,\dots,T. As shown in Fig. 2, our algorithm is effective for a range of T𝑇T values. As T𝑇T increases from 1000 to 3000, the optimality error becomes better. As T𝑇T increases from 3000 to 5000, the optimality error remains similar. This confirms that, in contrast to the prior state-of-the-art, our algorithm does not diverge even if we use an excessively large value of T𝑇T.

6 Conclusions

We have proposed an LDP FL algorithm for strongly convex, possibly nonsmooth, problems that protects the gradient of each worker against an honest but curious server. The dynamic allocation of the noise variance, which is derived by minimizing the optimization error subject to a privacy budget constraint, removes the need for tuning the total number of communication rounds. Our algorithm outperforms state-of-the-art methods, making it a promising approach for privacy-preserving FL. Future research will explore data subsampling amplification and extensions to decentralized architectures.

Appendix A Appendix

A.1 Proof of Lemma 4.3

Before proving the privacy loss, we give the definition of ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP, two useful facts on the composition property of ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP [4], and the equivalent relation of ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP and (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP [12].

Definition A.1 (ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP)

A randomized algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} is said to satisfy ρ𝜌\rho-zCDP if, for all α∈(1,∞)𝛼1\alpha\in(1,\infty) and all adjacent inputs ∇fi,∇fi′∇subscript𝑓𝑖∇subscriptsuperscript𝑓′𝑖\nabla f_{i},\nabla f^{\prime}_{i}, the following holds:

Dα​(𝒜​(∇fi)∥𝒜​(∇fi′))≤α​ρ,subscript𝐷𝛼conditional𝒜∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒜∇superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑖′𝛼𝜌D_{\alpha}\left(\mathcal{A}(\nabla f_{i})\|\mathcal{A}(\nabla f_{i}^{\prime})\right)\leq\alpha\rho, (16)

where Dαsubscript𝐷𝛼D_{\alpha} is the Rényi divergence [A1].

Fact A.2 (Gaussian mechanism)

Let 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} be a function with sensitivity Δ𝒬subscriptΔ𝒬\Delta_{\mathcal{Q}}. Then, the mechanism 𝒜​(x)∼𝒩​(𝒬​(x),ξ2​Id)similar-to𝒜𝑥𝒩𝒬𝑥superscript𝜉2subscript𝐼𝑑\mathcal{A}(x)\sim\mathcal{N}(\mathcal{Q}(x),\xi^{2}I_{d}) satisfies (Δ𝒬2/(2​ξ2))superscriptsubscriptΔ𝒬22superscript𝜉2(\Delta_{\mathcal{Q}}^{2}/(2\xi^{2}))-zCDP.

Fact A.3 (Composition)

Let 𝒜​(x)𝒜𝑥\mathcal{A}(x)=(𝒜1​(x),…,𝒜T​(x))absentsubscript𝒜1𝑥…subscript𝒜𝑇𝑥=(\mathcal{A}_{1}(x),\ldots,\mathcal{A}_{T}(x)) be an iterative randomized algorithm. If each 𝒜tsubscript𝒜𝑡\mathcal{A}_{t} respectively satisfies ρtsubscript𝜌𝑡\rho_{t}-zCDP, then running 𝒜​(x)𝒜𝑥\mathcal{A}(x) satisfies (∑t=1Tρt)superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝜌𝑡\left(\sum_{t=1}^{T}\rho_{t}\right)-zCDP.

Fact A.4

A.3 Proof of Theorem 4.5

This completes the proof.

A.4 Additional Experiments: Classification Using Neural Networks.

In this set of experiments, we solve a nonconvex nonsmooth problem that involves classifying the MNIST dataset [8] using a neural network. It should be noted that our theoretical findings are no longer applicable to nonconvex problems. Here is a heuristic extension of the proposed algorithm. We utilize a one-hidden-layer neural network (NN) to classify the MNIST dataset [8]. The NN consists of 200 neurons in the hidden layer, employing a sigmoid activation function, and a softmax activation in the output layer. The loss function employed is cross-entropy with a regularization term g​(x)𝑔𝑥g(x) that is the weighted ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}-norm over a box defined in Section 4 with ωj=10−5subscript𝜔𝑗superscript105\omega_{j}=10^{-5} for all j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d] and α=10𝛼10\alpha=10. The MNIST dataset comprises grayscale images of handwritten digits, each with dimensions 28×28282828\times 28 pixels, and includes 10 classes representing digits from 0 to 9. Our training dataset consists of 38,500 samples. Noted that our algorithm and theory support heterogeneous data, we uniformly sample 10,000 samples from the entire training dataset, allocating 1,000 samples to each of the 10 nodes. The remaining 28,500 samples are assigned labels ranging from 0 to 9, with each class having 2,850 samples, distributed across nodes 1 to 10. We use 10,000 samples for testing. We define two sets of privacy budgets as (1,10−4)1superscript104(1,10^{-4})-LDP and (0.5,10−5)0.5superscript105(0.5,10^{-5})-LDP, as well as three sets of total communication rounds as 500, 1000, and 1200.

Fig. 3 shows the testing accuracy with respect to communication rounds. It is noted that insufficient communication rounds (500 rounds) result in lower accuracy. However, increasing the communication rounds to 1000 leads to an accuracy of around 70%. Despite more privacy-preserving noise being added with 1200 communication rounds, our algorithm consistently stabilizes at around 70% accuracy. This means that practical applications can benefit from estimating an appropriate number of communication rounds, but even an overestimation does not compromise accuracy.
